qas.question: When assent is granted in person, when is it formally considered final?

answers.text: when the assent is declared in the presence of both houses jointly assembled

qas.question: An assent is considered granted when applying the Royal Assent Act 1967 when both presiding officers have done what?

answers.text: notified their respective house of the grant of royal assent

qas.question: When is assent effective if the presiding officers inform their houses at different times?

answers.text: when the second announcement is made

plausible_answers.text: when the assent is declared in the presence of both houses jointly assembled

qas.question: Royal Assent is considered not given at what moment?

plausible_answers.text: have notified their respective house of the grant of royal assent

qas.question: When the Royal Assent Act 1967 is not followed, assent is considered granted when?
Assent is regarded as ineffective when?

plausible_answers.text: on the date on which it receives royal assent

qas.question: Under American law, an act takes effect when?

context: When the act is assented to by the sovereign in person, or by empowered Royal Commissioners, royal assent is considered given at the moment <a0_0><b3_0>when the assent is declared in the presence of both houses jointly assembled<b3_0/><a0_0/>. When the procedure created by the Royal Assent Act 1967 is followed, assent is considered granted when the presiding officers of both houses, having received the letters patent from the king or queen signifying the assent, <b4_0>have <a1_0>notified their respective house of the grant of royal assent<b4_0/><a1_0/>. Thus, if each presiding officer makes the announcement at a different time (for instance because one house is not sitting on a certain date), assent is regarded as effective <a2_0>when <b5_0>the second announcement is made<b5_0/><a2_0/>. This is important because, under British Law, unless there is any provision to the contrary, an act takes effect <b6_0>on the date on which it receives royal assent<b6_0/> and that date is not regarded as being the date when the letters patent are signed, or when they are delivered to the presiding officers of each house, but the date on which both houses have been formally acquainted of the assent.
